Award.AwardTitle: Identifying Genetic Determinants of Speciation from Genomic Maps of Ancestry in Hybrid Mice
Award.AbstractNarration:
Why are there so many species? The process by which two species are generated from one - speciation - is a major determinant of biodiversity. When species hybridize in nature, some parts of their genomes are exchanged and others are not. Those regions of the genome that are not exchanged keep the species separate. By identifying those incompatible regions in species of mice, this research will reveal genetic mechanisms responsible for speciation (and biodiversity). Another novel contribution of this research will be the development of new approaches that analyze entire genomes, instead of one region at a time. The project will combine research with teacher training to share discoveries with the public. In addition to expanding evolutionary knowledge, this research will benefit applied fields, including human health. For example, the framework developed in this project can be used to understand the current reproductive effects of historical mating between humans and Neanderthals.

This research will provide new theoretical and empirical frameworks for measuring gene flow between species in hybrid zones. The focus will be ancestry junctions - those points along chromosomes where ancestry switches from one species to the other. In contrast to existing analyses of hybrid genomes, this approach will easily scale to entire genomes. Computer simulations will be used to quantify the effects of selection, migration and genetic drift on ancestry junctions across the genome. A range of genetic architectures of reproductive isolation will be investigated to determine the conditions under which selection against hybrids leaves detectable genomic signatures. This theoretical framework will be applied to new genomic data collected in hybrids between two subspecies of house mice that are excellent models for studying speciation in progress. Incompatible genomic regions responsible for reproductive barriers between new species will be identified.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The world is full of species, but the process by which new species arise remains mysterious. Studying groups of creatures that are on their way to becoming species can reveal the necessary steps in the process. The main goals of this project were to use natural hybrids to identify genes that cause reproductive barriers between new species and to develop educational activities to help students learn how new species arise.

 

We discovered that genes that reduce the fertility or viability of natural hybrids show specific patterns that distinguish them from other genes. In hybrids, reproductive barrier genes have unusual ancestries and unusual frequencies of mutations. Using these signatures, it is possible to scan the DNA of hybrids to find genes involved in the origin of species. We developed new methods to take hybrid DNA sequences as inputs and produce a list of reproductive barrier genes. We also found that the full DNA sequence of hybrids contains details about how often hybridization occurs and how long ago it started. These discoveries came from simulating hybrid zones ? places where groups of creatures meet and mate in nature ? many times in a computer and examining the results.

 

We studied the DNA of natural hybrids between two groups of house mice on their way to becoming new species. Which group each piece of DNA was inherited from changes quickly along each chromosome in hybrids, indicating that the two groups have been mixing their DNA for a long time. Ancestry changes more slowly across the X chromosome, suggesting genes on this chromosome contribute to reproductive barriers between the two groups.

 

To help high school students learn how new species arise, we created an educational card game called Speciation. Each card describes a type of reproductive barrier and a real example of this barrier in nature. Teams create new species by collecting diverse reproductive barriers with enough strength to last. Card decks, which are now in the process of being professionally printed, will be distributed to high school biology classrooms from across Wisconsin soon. We hope playing this card game makes learning speciation fun for students and teachers.
